results.title: Stencil colouring
results.brief_description: When Alexandre Volkoff brought the story of history’s greatest lover to the screen in Casanova (1927), he definitely needed colour. Pathé Frères developed a stencil technqiue for colouring films that brought Casanova’s costumes alive and colour to his lovers’ cheeks.

constellations_primary.name: Evolution of colour
constellations_primary.description: From stenciling film frames through to the survival of Technicolor after Hollywood stopped using it, this Constellation links early cinema to some of the world's greatest films.

results.description: When Alexandre Volkoff brought the story of history’s greatest lover to the screen in Casanova (1927), he definitely needed colour. While Technicolor was decades away, the French production company Pathé Frères had developed a technique of stencil-colouring films around 1908. This process used a template for each colour – usually between three and six – and applied it frame by frame. Pathé continued innovating, developing mechanical devices to make the process faster and easier for the more than 400 women colourists working at the company. Thanks to Pathé’s stencil method, Casanova’s costumes shimmered in pink, orange and yellow, and rosy blushes graced his lovers’ cheeks.
description_for_label: When Alexandre Volkoff brought the story of history’s greatest lover to the screen in Casanova (1927), he definitely needed colour. While Technicolor was decades away, the French production company Pathé Frères had developed a technique of stencil-colouring films around 1908. Pathé continued innovating, developing mechanical devices to make the process faster and easier for the more than 400 women colourists working at the company. Thanks to Pathé’s stencil method, Casanova’s costumes shimmered in pink, orange and yellow, and rosy blushes graced his lovers’ cheeks.

results.title: Splitting Time
results.brief_description: Splitting Time explores the contribution of early photographers to the development of the moving image.

constellations_primary.name: Innovation, technology and design: Edweard Muybridge
constellations_primary.description: A focus on the discovery, inspiration and innovation at the heart of moving image history

results.description:
By increasing camera shutter speeds and slowing time to a fraction of a second, British American photographer Eadweard Muybridge laid the foundation of the moving image. Using multiple cameras triggered by trip wires, he captured a galloping horse in sequential images, reproduced them in a zoetrope and created the world’s first moving photographs.

While Muybridge froze moments on separate photographs, French scientist Étienne-Jules Marey’s chronophotographic technique captured kinetic motion through multiple exposures in one photo. He used a photographic rifle with a revolving cylinder that shot 12 frames a second.

Meanwhile, American professor Harold ‘Doc’ Edgerton’s pioneering development of the electric stroboscopic flash suspended movement, stopping skipping ropes mid-swing – and even speeding bullets.
description_for_label:
By increasing camera shutter speeds and slowing time to a fraction of a second, British American photographer Eadweard Muybridge laid the foundation of the moving image. Using multiple cameras triggered by trip wires, he captured a galloping horse in sequential images, reproduced them in a zoetrope and created the world’s first moving photographs.

While Muybridge froze moments on separate photographs, French scientist Étienne-Jules Marey’s chronophotographic technique captured kinetic motion through multiple exposures in one photo. He used a photographic rifle with a revolving cylinder that shot 12 frames a second.

Meanwhile, American professor Harold ‘Doc’ Edgerton’s pioneering development of the electric stroboscopic flash suspended movement, stopping skipping ropes mid-swing – and even speeding bullets.

results.title: Spectacle

constellations_primary.name: Hell no, we won't go
constellations_primary.description: The cultural, social, psychological and political effects of the Vietnam War have been explored through cinematic classics, musicals and comedies.

constellations_primary.name: Rodney King LA Riots
constellations_primary.description: The brutal beating of Rodney King by the LAPD was caught on amateur videotape and became what is arguably the first video of police brutality to go viral before the internet. It was a catalyst for the 1992 LA riots, which has influenced media ever since.

constellations_primary.name: Spectacle
constellations_primary.description: The moving image has captured some of history’s biggest moments. From newsreel shorts in cinemas before the show to the arrival of TV, nightly news and the 24-hour news cycle to social media, news has become a spectacle.

results.description: The moving image has captured some of history’s biggest moments. In the early 20th century, Australians received much of their information from newsreel shorts in cinemas before the main feature. This shared viewing experience represented the way film, and the media, could turn current events into spectacles, and these shorts were an important predecessor to the nightly news that followed when television arrived in the 1950s. As the century progressed, world events were broadcast directly into homes, helping accelerate social, political and cultural change. Today, technological advancements also fuel new formats, like the 24-hour news cycle and social media, which blur the lines between information and entertainment while reflecting the hope, tragedy and joy of human experience.
description_for_label: The moving image has captured some of history’s biggest moments. results.title: Special effects in Blade Runner (Spinners)
results.brief_description: Blade runner Rick Deckard (Harrison Ford) hunts rogue replicants through the rain-drenched, neon-lit streets of a futuristic Los Angeles in Ridley Scott’s groundbreaking Blade Runner (1982).

constellations_primary.name: The Kubrick connection
constellations_primary.description: The visual effects for Blade Runner drew on a number of techniques from other iconic films, including two of Stanley Kubrick's masterpieces.

results.description:
Blade runner Rick Deckard (Harrison Ford) hunts rogue replicants through the rain-drenched, neon-lit streets of a futuristic Los Angeles in Ridley Scott’s groundbreaking Blade Runner (1982).   

Aside from the influential dystopian setting, Blade Runner is lauded for its striking visual effects, particularly the ‘spinners’ – hi-tech cars that soar through the streets and the sky. Scott was inspired by imagery in several of these books. Futurist and industrial designer Syd Mead also contributed, helping design the sci-fi world around the cars.   

Spinner models were filmed against a black screen and then superimposed on the model shots of LA. Three life-size versions of the spinners were also created. These flew on wires that were later painted out of the shots, while interior shots were filmed against a green screen.
description_for_label:
Blade runner Rick Deckard (Harrison Ford) hunts rogue replicants through the rain-drenched, neon-lit streets of a futuristic Los Angeles in Ridley Scott’s groundbreaking Blade Runner (1982).   

Aside from the influential dystopian setting, Blade Runner is lauded for its striking visual effects, particularly the ‘spinners’ – hi-tech cars that soar through the streets and the sky. Scott was inspired by imagery in several of these books. Futurist and industrial designer Syd Mead also contributed, helping design the sci-fi world around the cars.

results.title: Special effects in Blade Runner (Hades landscape)
results.brief_description: Blade Runner (1982) opens on a hellish Los Angeles skyline with no horizon in sight, but it’s far less expansive than it seems. Known as the ‘Hades landscape’, it was made from models, matte paintings and used practical effects to look like a living city.

constellations_primary.name: Neo-noir
constellations_primary.description: Blade Runner's retro-futurist setting lends it a timeless quality, while also connecting it to the past and the future.

results.description:
Blade Runner (1982) opens on a hellish Los Angeles skyline with no horizon in sight. While the explosive cityscape appears endless, it’s far less expansive than it seems.   

Known as the ‘Hades landscape’, it was created on an enormous table (15ft by 8ft) with models that were acid-etched into brass. Bigger models were placed at the front and smaller ones at the back. This created the illusion of depth, which was aided by filling the room with smoke. The model also contained thousands of fibre-optic cables to make it look like a living city, while the erupting flames were superimposed onto the landscape shot. 

These four matte paintings you see here were used like a green screen – part of a shot is cut out of the frame and then is replaced by the painting.
description_for_label:
Blade Runner (1982) opens on a hellish Los Angeles skyline with no horizon in sight. While the explosive cityscape appears endless, it’s far less expansive than it seems.   

Known as the ‘Hades landscape’, it was created on an enormous table (15ft by 8ft) with models that were acid-etched into brass. Bigger models were placed at the front and smaller ones at the back. This created the illusion of depth, which was aided by filling the room with smoke. The model also contained thousands of fibre-optic cables to make it look like a living city, while the erupting flames were superimposed onto the landscape shot. 

These four matte paintings you see here were used like a green screen – part of a shot is cut out of the frame and then is replaced by the painting.

group.title: Concept sketches, design drawing and elevations

results.title: Sony Digital Handycam DCR-VX1000
results.brief_description: Sony released the Handycam DCR-VX1000 in 1995, the same year digital video launched. It wasn’t just popular for amateurs and at-home users, but it was also deployed by professional news outlets looking to replace the large, expensive, shoulder mounted Betacam cameras.

constellations_primary.name: Fish-eyes and fun times
constellations_primary.description: This Constellation starts with The Favourite and ends up at Rambo, and was made by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies student Daniel Bryan.

results.description: Digital video was launched in 1995 and Sony released the Handycam DCR-VX1000 that same year. It was not only hugely popular for the amateur and at-home user, but it was also deployed by professional news outlets looking for something to replace the large, expensive, shoulder-mounted Betacam cameras. The camcorder was the answer, with high image quality matched by its affordability and portability. These same traits are what saw it became a seminal tool for the creation of skate cinema, with the Handycam DCR-VX1000 often paired with a fish-eye lens and used to record groundbreaking videos in the genre.
description_for_label: Digital video was launched in 1995 and Sony released the Handycam DCR-VX1000 that same year. It was not only hugely popular for the amateur and at-home user, but it was also deployed by professional news outlets looking for something to replace the large, expensive, shoulder-mounted Betacam cameras. The camcorder was the answer, with high image quality matched by its affordability and portability. These same traits are what saw it became a seminal tool for the creation of skate cinema, with the Handycam DCR-VX1000 often paired with a fish-eye lens and used to record groundbreaking videos in the genre.
